div.head: LONDON PRESS ON EGYPT.
div.p: So great is the interest now being taken in Egypt by the home Press, that certain London

papers have expressed their intention to send out special correspondents to study the affairs of the country. Up to the present we have | always considered that the average Britisher showed a remarkable ignorance of this country, in spite of its importance both politically and commercially, and we are glad to observe any : has for long been accused, and to a large measure rightly, of lack of enterprise, and the business man of Egypt especially grumbles at his hesitation co put British goods on the market here and the restrictions with which he hedges round his would-be agents. On every side we see foreign firms creeping in where we should have come in first, and, though we hardly agree with the pessimists who prognosticate the day when Great Britain will be a secondary or even tertiary commercial power in Egypt, we fully agree with those who say that the Old Country fails to realise what an enormous field is open to her song. The London journalists who are about to visit this country have, therefore, a great and serious opportunity before them, and we await the results of their visits with interest and even with anxiety. The political and commercial affairs of Egypt are not such as can be grasped by a cursory glance. Writers of such
articles as we look forward to reading must, necessarily, generalise and this entails doep study and searching inquiry among competent
men who know the country au fond, as far as that is possible. It is only in such a way that in the articles can be made of real value..

We do not give this warning without reason.About a fortnight ago there appeared in a prominent London paper an article of a column 2 and a half purporting to deal with the future in Egypt. If the writer's idea was to provide the reading public with facts which might indicate to them what the future of Egypt is likely to be, he failed miserably. The article, in feed, is chiefly remarkable for its verbosity, and a considerable part of it is devoted to a picturesque description of a journey which he made to Zagazig and a hardly more à propos
account of an interview which he had with an officer who served under Arabi Pasha at the article there is much fault to be found, As an opening sentence the writers says: "Ten

years ago Egypt was a country of the dead.”.All who have studied this country must know that in 1896, during which year her revenues totalled L.E. 10,260,000, she was very much alive, and had already made a good stride 1towards her present-day prosperity. Ten years ago her imports showed an increase over the previous year of L.E. 1,271,000 and her

exports an increase of L.E. 568,000. Ten years ago Egypt exported 4,008,000 cantars of cotton, an increase of 148,000 cantars over 1895. Ten years ago the railway receipts amounted L.E. 1,822,000 and 9,864,000 passengers were conveyed by the rail ways; telegraphic receipts
amounted to L.E. 53,000; 1,286 steamships cleared 1,943,000 tons of goods at where the receipts of the port were L.E.141,000. And this from a country of the dead!.

British officers are broken off owing to fresh demands of Valiente. H.M.S. Pathfinder has returned home from Tetuan with Valiente's brother.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: A POUNDLING. --A new-born child was found abandoned yesterday in Sisters-street ad taken to hospital.
SUEZ CANAL.--222 vessels passed through the Canal from the 6th to the 20th inet., th
does from which amounted to fra. 6,109,689.11
STRAY Dogs. - Stray and ownerless dog found in the Sayeda Zonab quarter of Cairo during the night of Tuesday, will be poisoned by the police.
Fire broke out yesterday afternoon in the house of Mr. Antoine Anagasto, at Ramleh. It was extinguished by means of a fire pump, the damage being estimated at £150.
SANITARY DEPARTMENT. --On the advice of the Director-General of the Sanitary Department, the Ministry of the Interior bag authorised M. Jean Cacaris, chemist, to practise Egypt.
KASR EL ANI HOSPITAL +Dr. A. H. Brehaut has been appointed resident medical officer at the Kasr el Aini Hospital at a salary of L.E. 20.833 m. per month, dating from the 17th inst.
ROYAL BERKS. -A detachment of the 2nd Battalion Royal Berkshire Regiment, in
charge of two officers, will leave Sidi Gaber station for Caito, en route to Khartoum, by the 3.49 p.m. train on Wednesday next.

THE RAMADAN NEw Moon. -Several observers from the Cairo Gouvernorat will observe the rising of the new moon on Saturday next so as to be able to officially confirm the commencement of Ramadan on the following day.

BATHING IN THE NILE.-An British Army Order, issued on Saturday, states that "owing to the dangerous nature of thunder currents in theNile, all bathing in this river is prohibited except where locally published permit it."

-We are informed that Mr. Pericles Glymnopoulos, of the advisory board of this company in Egypt, has arrived in Paris, and was expected in London on or about the 20th inst, to confer with the directors on the company's
FREEMASONRY.-It will be a source of gratification to the many friends in Egypt. of the

late Mr. Frank Allchin to learn that at the recent elections for the Royal Masonic Institute made his public entry for Girls in London, his daughter, Florice Emperor the return of the Violet, was among the 29 successful candidates, having secured a very large number of votes. This is the second of Mr. Allchin's daughters to be admitted to this excellent institution, her sister having entered a couple of years ago.

NILE TRIPS FOR RESIDENTS.-- As is usual at the commencement of the winter reason, for the first two or three sailings of their Nile steamers to Assouan, Messrs. Thos. Cook & Son, Limited, make a special reduction for residents of this country. The rates they are putting into operation for this season are £25, instead of £50, for the tourist service by the sailings to Assouan ex Cairo November 14, 29, and December 5, and £15, instead of £22, for the express service, by the siblings ex Cairo November 3, 10, 17, 24, and December 4 and 8. The journey to Assouan and back by tourist steamer takes 20 days, and the fare (which includes sight-seeing, etc.) is first-rate in every respect; the express steamers occupy 19 days, four days of which are spent at the hotel at Assouan, and three days at Luxor. Doubtless with the exceptionally hot summer which residents have experienced this year, many Government officials and others will be glad to avail themselves of one of these sailings.

div.head: THE COMING SEASON.
div.p: Prince Leopold of Battenburg is coming to Egypt for the benefit of his health, and will leave England in the S.S. Ormuz on November 18.
Lord and Lady Carton are likely to pay Lord Cromer a short visit in Cairo on their way to England next month.
The Dowager Countess of Donoughmore and Lady Norab Hely-Hutobinson are to winter in Egypt. They have arrived in London en route.

Egypt is how free from bubonic plague, and the weekly bulletin issued by the Sanitary Department states that no case was reported during last week. Three cases, however, remained under treatment after the issue of the previous bulletin, but of these two have recovered, and one has ended fatally. All these three casos occurred at Alexandria.
In view of the present freedom of the country from plague no-farther official bulletins will be issued unless a new case should be notified.
H.H. the Khedive will spend to-day at Montazah Palace and will come to Ras-el-Tin at an early hour to-morrow morning for his farewell reception before leaving for Cairo.

Medinet al-Fayoum, Saturday Mr. and Mrs. Reid and Mr. Boyd of the American Mission, have returned from holiday in the U.S.A. The work of the mission continues to have an excellent got, and the mission schools are thronged with children from the district. I vited the Medinet el Fayoum girls' school the other day and was (August 16. 1892) and was very kindly shown over the school by Miss Martin, the head-mistress, who has met with great success in teaching the girls, of every nationality, who attend the school.
TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.

Sir,- In the "Bourse Egyptienne" of the 19th nst., repeated in the "Phare d'Alexandrie" of the 20th inet., under the heading "Bulletin de la Boarse," a movement is said to be advocated by a Cairo firm of brokers and a certain number of local shareholders of the above company, with a view to eappross the London board of adıninistration, and to substitute an Egyptian board of directors to take over the entire management of the affairs of the company, on the supposed grounds of continued friction between the present London and Cairo boards . I beg to state that this agitation against the Chairman and London board of directora does not emanate from the local board, as sach, whose sole members are Mr. Loosdorfer, Mr. Hooker (ex-managing director), and myself. My colleague, Mr. Lonsdorfer, has been absent in Barope since the early days of September, and does not return to Egypt till the 7th November, whilst I personally am al on the strong supporter of the London board in all their actions.--Yours faithfully,

A special service was held at St Mark's Church, Alexandria, yesterday, and a trophy and inscription, simple and in excellent taste, designed by Rear-Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, were erected for the occasion. It consisted of the famous signal Eagland expects, etc.," below which which came the great admiral's dying words, "For God and my country," and the name Horatio Nelson in white letters on red. In the porch was hang a notice on which appeared Nelson's portrait and an exact reproduction in the international code colors of his Trafalgar signal, with an appeal from free from the Nelson Centenary Memorial Fand appended. Special hymns were sung for the occasion, and the Rev. R. Wormell adapted appropriate words to Sir Arthur Sullivan's well-known Jabilee hymn Oh, King of Kings, whose reign of old.' one has ended fatally. All these rred at Alexandria.

A letter which has reached us from Syria shows that the stories of a general conflict be tween Bedouins and Droses in the Hauran have been much exaggerated. It appears that a Druse caravan, while returning to the Hauran from Damascus some six weeks ago, was attacked by a gang of Bedouins, and lost two men and most of its camela. On the news reaching the Hagran 300 Drase cavaliers decided to make reprisale. Riding some days over desolate country in the east of the Hauran, they s urprised the oftending tribe and took 700 camels. Two hundred of the raiders returned with their spoil, the remainder, unsatisfied with their booty, rode on and captured some cattle, only to find themselves face to face with an overwhelming force of Bedouing who had gathered to repel the attack. Heavily out numbered, the Hundred Druses bad to retire after two days' fighting, losing twenty men and as many horses.

Among the fallen notables were the sors of of Sheiku Selim el Atrash and of Sheikh Said Nasr both only seventeen years of age. Five Bedonin lenders were killed. The whole force of the Hanran Dow prepared to attack the Bedonios, when Naz'ın Pasha, Vali of Damakous, intervened, and the Druses, whosa feelings toward this excellent governor are most friendly, agreed to submit the dispute to him for settlement.

The sad news comes from Constantinople of the the death of Mr. William Shortland Richards H.B.M.'8 Conaal at Damasous. Mr. Richards appointed student interpreter in 1877 became vice-consul at Mosal in 18-3 and at Bourgas in 1885. He was then promoted to be Consul for the E. Coast of the Red Sea (August 16, 1892) and was attacked and severely wounded by Bedouins in May, 1895 receiving compensation from the Turkish Go vernment. In 1896 he was transferred to Damascus. An excellent linguist, firm and energetic console, always willing to give information and advira M. Richards won
formation and advice, Mr. Richards won the respect of all who knew him. The writer has a

very pleasant recollection of the helpful kindness shown him by Mr. Richards, who was then in very poor health, at Damascus this year, while the firmness he showed when called to Beyroat, in the absence on leave of the Consul-General, during the last disturbances , will long be remembered by the peaceable inhabitants--and by Rashid Bay.

Accompanied by the civil and military members of his household, HE. Ghazi Ahmed Mokhtar Pasha, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, leaves Hadra on Taekday next by special train leaving at 9 20 a.m. and arriving at Cairo station at 12.35 p.m.

A dinner party was given yesterday by Col. Utaonomiya, of the Japanese General Staff, before leaving for Tokio, on the terrace of the Grand Continental Hotel, Cairo. Among the co lonel's guests were Major-General Sir F. R. Wingate Pa hs, Brig-General Ballook, General Sir R. von Slatin Pasha, Lient. Col. Lord E . Cecil, Col. Bernard Bey, Col. Matchell, Col. Hunter, Major Kenney Herbert, Major LStack, Major Davidson, Mr. Bonham Carter, Mr. Bonus, Capt. H. Lewin, Capt. R. Oven, and Capt. R. Collins.

Lews Tharneyssen Pashs, A.D.C. to H.H. the Khedive, and Tito Hakekian Pashs were among the large number of well-known residents who returned from Europe to-day by the Austrian packet, and whose names will la found in another column.
Sir Horace Pinching, Director-General of the Sanitary Department, has returned from leave.
Little Miss Victoria Wiogato, daughter of H.B. the Governor-General of the Sadan, Was
among the passengers who arrived from Eng land by the new Moss liner to-day.
We regret to announce the death of Mah mood Effendi Kamel, sanitary inspector the Tahta distriot, Ghirgeh province, which took place on the 18th inst.

div.head: CONSTANTINOPLE NOTES.
div.p: M. Gryparis, Hellenio Minister at Constan tinople, has left such a pleasant memory in Egypt, that news of his forthcoming marriage with Mlle Ralli will be read with pleasure.he marriage takes place at Athens, and numerous well-known Greek residenta of Constantinople and the Greek Consul-General for Adrianople have already left for the Hellenic Capital. The "best mon" will be M. Rallys, president of the Council of Ministers, and M. Pesmazoglu, director-general of the Bank of Athens. Great preparations are being made at the Greek Legation here for the arrival of M. and Mme Gryparis, who only intend to make a short stay in Paris before returning to Constantinople. Some great receptions are expected at the legation this winter.

Sherif Aly Paaha has just been appointed Emir of Mecoa. The new Emir is nophew of the llate Aan-el-Rafik, his predecessor in the post Sherif Aly has sent a message of loyalty and thanks to the Sultan. Meantime the sacred caravan has left for Mecca and Medins with the usual accompaniment of festivities and religious ceremonies. Husni Bey is in charge of the caravan and escort.
We may add that an exo The marriage of Elias Ef. Kudai, Alexandria correspondent of our contemporary "Al

Mokattam," with Miss Anissah Jureidini took place yesterday afternoon at the Orthodox church of Saidat El Nijah. After the ceremony the bride and bridegroom received the congratulations of their friends at their new house it Bolkeley, Ramleb. It was a very pleasant evening to Mc. Kadsi's numerous friends. The wedding presents, which were tastefal and numerous, were shown in a special room. An excellent supper crowool the evening. Among those present were the three well-known poets, Ahmed Efendi Nessim, Shaikh Shaheem Bl khezea, and Abbus Eff. Ma fi; the latter extemporised some veraog wbich were much appreciated. Ahmed Effendi Nessim, who accompanied Shahee . Bey Macarius from Cairo to attend the ceremony, then resd a long and pretty poem, which he had composed, and drank to the health of the Rev. Archimandrite Ilia, who was prosent.
The new Mosa liner Monepthah arrived this morning from Liverpool, via Gibraltar, Algiers, and Malta, with passengers, mails, and general ourgo.

div.head: SITUATION IN MOROCCO.
div.p: HE ALLEGED GERMAN LOAN. team, and for a variety of rea
There are various indications of naval preparations being made in connection with the situation in Morocco. (Reuter)
TANGIER, October 30. The French cruiser Jeanne d'Aro bash here to support the Galilée in protecting French interests.
HOUSE OF COMMONS.-Sir E. Grey stated that, according to the latest information, El Raizuli had restored order in Arzlia. It was not proposed to send a man-of-war.
The news is refuted here that the German Minister at Pez is negotiating a small loan on behalf of the Moorish Government. He is acting entirely in accord with the Algeciras Conference. (Reuter)

div.head: FINAL BATTLE IN RUSSIA.
div.p: 4,000 students and others assembled yesterday at the University and adopted extreme revolutionary resolutions. A final battle is imminent, they say, in which despotism will food ita grave. The University has since been closed.
Eight men have been tried by drumhead court martial and executed in connection with the bomb oatrage of the 27. (Reuter)

div.head: PRUSSIAN POLAND.
div.p: Under instrüotions from their parents 45,000 Catholio children in Pragsian Poland refuse to receive religious instruction in the German language and are consistently punished. The Government approves of the polishing.(Reuter)

div.head: THE EDUCATION BILL.
div.p: HOUSE OF LORDS.-A detailed discussion on the Bducation Bill was started. Iatonas intere-t prevailed throughout. There was the largest attendance of Peers since the last Home Rule Bill. The galleries were thronged with Peeresses and Members of Parliament. Lord Heneage'
amendment, making religions instruction compulsory during school board, was carried by 256 votes to 56, in spite of the opposition of the Government (Router)

div.head: THE FRENCH COLONIES.
div.p: M. Eneroix, the now Minister of the Colonies, has declared that he is resolved to administer the Colonies on business lines and to make them pay by increasing the imports and exports. (Reuter)

div.head: THE LUTIN DISASTER.
div.p: The ongoity bold shows that the disaster to the Latin was not imputable to her commandant, Leabemat Pépoux. The faperal of the victims took place in the morning.(Havas)

div.head: PHILIPPINE ASSEMBLY.
div.p: President Roosevelt has fixed the elections for the first Philippine Assembly to take place in the Spring. (Reuter)

div.head: NEW GERMAN MINISTER AT CAIRO.
div.p: Count Bernstorff, Congal General at Cairo, will start to-morrow for Egypt. He dined with the Emperor and breakfast with Sir Frank Lascelles, the British Ambassador.(Reuter)

div.head: RIFLE SHOOTING IN SCHOOLS.
div.p: House of Commons. -Mr. Birrell explained that the rifle shooting experiment would be confined to five schools. No farther permission would be given., (Reuter)
The Booperor bas bertswed on M. Izwolsky the Grand Cross of the Red Eagle. (Reuter)
K. S. C. o. R. INNISKILLING FUSILIERS.

This return fixture was played at Gbezireb on Saturday, 28th inst. Several alterations were necessary in the composition of the home team, and for a variety of reasons Barnard, Breretoa, and Carry gave way to Fletcher, Ashcroft, and Lofton making a practically new forward line from that which drow with the same team a fortnight ago. Stout won the toss,and defended the pavilion goal. The advantage of the sun was considerable at first and enabled the home team to immediately become aggressive. Yates and Fletcher were early conspicuous, but found the defence equal to all emergencies, and for the most part the game was io midfield, where high kicking on the part of the defence deprived the game of much interest, as the ball was too frequently in touch.” Several useful runs were inaugurated by both forward lines, but each-Deeded finish, and lack of shooting power was lamentably evident on both sides. One effort however by the home forwarder deserved a better result. Receiving from Btherington Smith, Yates in tarn transferred to Fletcher, who, after taking it down the wing, went sorons a magnificent centre, only to see the opportunity go begging, through the inside forward not being op. A Second movement, however, carried oat on the same wing, enabled Yates to give to Deacon, who after tricking the, backs had little difficulty in placing the ball into the corner of the net, Howlett having no chance.

At half-time the advantage of the odd goal still rested with the home team. Bat on restarting the determination of the Inniskillings to get on terms was soon evident, and the home defence experienced more than one anxious moment. Welsh and Branagh, on the left, were always conspionour, the former especially playing. * particularly a clever game. The equalising goal came about ten minutes after the interval A clever run by the visiting left, which the defence failed to stop, gave Welsh a chance which he accepted, to send across a clever centre, and & misunderstanding between the back and goalkeeper left an absolutely open goal to Percy, who made no mistake. The pace of the game was well maintained to the end, but nothing further was stored and for the second time this season the result was a drawn match.

From an artistic point of view the game can hardly be voted a success. The pace of the ground and the light ball may have been responsible for the somewhat ragged exhibition. There was far too much high kicking, and combination was rather at a premium and good shooting entirely absent. A little more practice, however, shoall make all the difference and once together the home team should give a good account of themselves during the coming season. In the military team there are distinct possibilities: they pose as a c'ever left \wing, and Welsh was the best forward on the field. Smyth, too, at left half, was as usual ubiquitous, but the backs kick too hard and apparently without any consideration for the forwards in front of them.
K S.C. -Morrison, goal ; Stoot and Wyatt, backs ; Wesley, Rivers-Smith, and Eherington Smith, half-backs ; Lofton, Ashcroft, Deacon, forwards.
RI.P.-Bowlott, goal ; Pte Lyons and Pte Ward, bricks ; Cpl. Miller, Sergt. Walker and Pte Smyth, half-backs : Ptes. Hatton; Percy, Higginson, Branagh, and Welsh, forwards.

div.head: PITH OF THE PRESS.

p.hi: The Lords and the Education BIII.

div.p: The decision to recommend the postponement of the further consideration of the Education Bill until a final judgment has been delivered in the West Riding case is a naturals and indeed almost a necessary consequence of the decision to appeal against the judgment of | 8 the majority of the Court of Appeals. We have b already remarked that both good sense and good policy, even in the narrower party sense | 8 of the term, pointed to the wisdom and the expediency of having the appeal entered. The 8 game considerations point, not-less conclusive-| I ly, to the wisdom and expediency of having it | 6 determined before the House of Lords are invited to proceed with the Education Bill. Until final judgment has been delivered upon the point raised in the West Riding case, P Diether the supporters nor the opponents of that mengare can debate it with any assurance that they rightly understand the present situation of the education question. The Bill, no doubt, zovers many other points besides that which is in controversy in the West Riding casa; bat its main object, we have been con. stantly told, is to remedy a grievance which the judgment of the Court of Appeal affirms to be a non-existent grievance. The Government would clearly stand at a disadvantage in pressing the House of Lords to legislate on the supposition that the highest Court which has spoken on the subject is wrong, and that it may hereafter be reversed when the case comes on, in ordinary course, before that House as the Court of final appeal. (“Times.”) Parliament 1 A Waning Attraction.

Parliament rassembles to-day, after a quiet And rather doll regas. Though there are elements in the situation that promise, or threaten, 1 st a lively time, it cannot be said that there sa is mach, if any, public excitement. The fact of whether it is welcomed or deplored, is india- ne putable that Parliamentary proceedings are I go fast losing their interest for a great maps of Be people. The bare results of the day's sitting w are all that the average man cares about, and fa the number of those who read even the machcortailed reports of speeches is diminishing. There are advantages and drawbacks in this growing indifference. At the present moment we are inclined to think that th3 profit preponderates over the 1088. ("Telegraph.") The Empire and the Navy.

One of the first matters with which Parlia- | a ment will deal with the intended redaction of the Navy. As we have consistently maintained by tained, it is above all things necessary that st this question, like all questions affecting the as national and Imperial defences, should be steadfastly treated as above all considerations TI of party politics. We regard any Government of what political complexion soever, insofar 03 as they fulfil their first date, which is the de dae and efficient maintenance of the sea * and land defences of the Empire, as entitled op 1.on this head to the gupport of every loyal

citizen. Conversely, we regard any Government. di ment, of wbat political complexion soever, af who sacrifice the efficiency of the Services, cil no matter what the pretext, as faithful th to their trust, and 28 no longer fit to bolded the power and the insignia of their high led 'office. It is a heavy indictment that the Govern.br ment will have to answer. If, we sincerely 80 hope, they eleet te abandon their intention | ac of disastrously crippling the efficiency of the Pleet, no one, as we have said, will more heartily support their action than ourselves. Bot, even so, it is idle to suppose that, however plausible the explanations presented, their reputation has not been seriously, perhaps irreparably, injared. The great body of the nation, although they may not be etirred to loud protest, are profoundly, discontented and distrustful. It will need moeh - very mach--to restore their confidence.

M. Clemenceau will probably prove to be the cost original Premier whom France bas bad since Gambetta. and the few facts known ás yet about his Ministry stamp him as a man of courage and ideas. He proposes to F place at the bead of the army his friend W General Picquart, who was op till Jaly a da colonel "en retraite," broken for his gallant . deteros of Major Dreyfus, and even expelled D from the Legion of Honour. General Picquart Pi bas 69. Mach ability and a character of soch rare independence and moral courage that' tio his promotion will be hailed abroad as a 0 striking act of reparation. If the French pro. F

duca a more reckless, reactionary type that some other peoples, they alsó develop a logic and & virility among their radical which we can only envy and admire. This choice will be sharply criticized, and it may be popular in the army, though the army after General André's period of "purification” is no longer what it was. ("Tribane”)

What is to be said of M. Clemenceau bim self ? He also was a figure in the great Dreyfa drama. He was Zola's Editor, one of those splendid statesmen journalists of whom France has in her day produced so many. This is the man who now steps up to the position of supreme executive power in France. Zola is Gideon and the dead, else perhaps he also might have been summoned to this astonishing Government. That it will work well we have every confidence, and this emergence of absolute uncompromising honesty in public affairs should stimulate English politicians to drop their wearisome compromises, and adopt in their place a touch of real conviction.
In his categorical repudiation of the late te besides that

Government in the so-called scheme of "dovlation,” Mr. Balfoar undoubtedly doesn't have much to relieve the apprehensions of Unionists in Ireland as well as in Great Britain. But whether be bas done enough to restore the entire confidence which alone can ensure a solid resistance to the proposals of the Liberal Government remains yet to be seen. Prima facie it would seem that Unionists have a right to demand that their leaders should disclose the scheme which was actually contemplated by the late Government in regard to Ireland and which, therefore, may be offered as a constructive alternative to the measure, which the present Extraction. Cabinet will sooner or later introduce. That some alternative scheme was entertained is at least a fair inference from Lord Lansdowne's se, or threaten, | statement at Nottingham that even when he said that there saw the second "devolution" draft in the bands bent. The fact, of Sir Antony MacDonnell did not think it necessary to communicate the fact to his colleagues. So far from damaging the reputation of Mr. great mass of Balfour and his Cabinet, sach a declaration day's sitting would do more than anything else to ensure the 88 abont, and fall restoration of the confidence which even ron the mach. I now have a bat partially established. diminishing

p.hi: Federal Conference on Education. h3 profit pre

div.p: The League of the Empire has succeeded in perfecting & scheme for holding a Federal Conference on Education in London in May next. The Colonial Office has, we understand, afforded valuable official encouragement in the matter, and the League has been authorized by the Secretary of State for the Colonies to necessary that state that the scheme bas bis sympathy and 1 affecting the assistance. The President of the English Board of Education has also given his support. The Board will be fally represented at the Conference, and Mr. Birrell will preside at the opening meeting. Invitations have been dispatched by favour of Lord Elgin to the Colonial Education Department, and the cooperation of the Indian Government has also been requested. Educational authorities in different countries have expressed their warm approval regarding the scheme, and the Council of the League of the Empire h28 confidence, therefore, in carrying forward the Imperial education work with which it has been entrusted, and asks the help of all concerned in bringing it to a successful issue. That, we are sure, will be readily accorded, for the object is an altogether excellent one.

The machinery of the Empire is hopelessly out of gear, and is in need of entire reconstruction. The inability of our present Ministers to see beyond our own shores or to grasp the larger be interests of Empire is being daily brought into greater prominence and greater prominence, and it is safa to say that since their return to power more dissatisfaction and indignation has been caused throughout our colonies than would have been conceived to be possible in the time. ("Globe.")

p.hi: "Over half of the population of Canada suffer from some form of catarrh during the course of the year. This demonstrates the great need of Peruna in every home to protect the family against all catarrhal diseases.”--S. B. HARTMAN, M. D.

The "Journal of Commerce and Commercial Bulletin” (New York) contains the following

Sir,- The Bank of Bngland recently sent £1,000,000 to Egypt, and attention has been directed to the general condition of that country by & special Consular Report entitled "Progressive Egypt '' (Sept. 17). The conclusions at which Consular Agent Pepper arrives point to the bursting of a number of "speculative bubbles” founded on the familiar practice of converting suburban acreage into toma lots, with a rise in "price," which is called an enhanced "value." American manufacturers are, nevertheless, advised to cultivate Egyptian trade, and cautioned against demanding cash on delivery, or giving shorter oredit than three months. Lord Cromer in his last report on Egypt (April) says that while so far as be is "able to forecast the fatore, no sufficient ground exists for holding possitistic views," be concedes that the great rise in the value of land, in the sadden rush which has been made | to invest capital in various commercial undertakings, the destruction of the sogar indāstry -as the result of dealing with the land formerly planted with cane--and other causes have "tended to foster A suspicion that Egypalatian affairs generally are QD8oond, and that a und reaction, accompanied possibly by disastrous consequences, will probably take place before long" (p. 17).

The financial disturbance in Egypt twenty five years ago had little effect outside of three or four of the principal banking houses of the day and their clients. The total unsecured debt at the time of the British-vouupation (1882) es was about $250,000,000 ; and there were no local financial corporations of the elightest international importance. This is changed. A. flood, sach as those of 1861, 1868, 1874, and 1878, would impair the ability of English, French and German banks of the highest standing to hold American securities or assist in carrying out projected enterprises. The Egyptian debt itself, deducting the amount realized by the sale of collaterals, has not increased much over 70 por conta side the British-ocsopation, with nothing to show for it as an asset, bat at least $600,000,000 of "capital" has been placed there. As " imports, including specie, ral have for two years exceeded the exports," Lord Cromer remarks that "should this influx nd, of capital at any time dease or diminish, tha Ebe external debt of Egypt will be increased by the amount due to the foreign investor on the to capital now flowing into the country." div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujourd'hui à midi et demie.) La fermeté continue à régner, ainsi que l'animation. Les échanges les plus importants ont été effectués en Union Foncière, Comptoir, Estates, Trust, National Bank, Delta Land et Nile Lund.

Des réalisations ont ramené la Behera de 45 * 44 1/2 et la Daïra de 16 15/16 4 16 7/8, mais les autres valeurs foncières sont généralement bien teņaes : l'Union Foncière, de plus en plus recherchée, atteint. 69/16; la Delta Land s'avance 808si de 4 1/32 à 4 1/16, la Nile Land de 16 13/6 & 17 ; les Estates sont un peu plus faibles à 2 3/16 et le Cheik Padl à 111.

La Privilégiée Bière d'Alexandrie réactionnel de 222 & 210-220, tandis que la Bière du Caire monte de 135 & 136 la Privilégiée et de 72 3/4 " à 78 la Dividende. Les Cotton Mills s'avancent de 6/3 à 7, les Ninkovich Hôtels. de 18 1/4 å 18 5/16, les Sucreries de 23 à 21.

De 147 les Lots Taros progressent à 149, tandis que la Cassa di Sconto réactionnel de 238 8/4 à 238 l'ancienne et de 2331 à 233 la poubelle. On offre la Land Bank à 9 et la Banque d'Orient à 134. Le Crédit Franco Égyptien 8st demandé à 5 19/32.

Le rapport de Comptoir a produit une bonne impression : Action ancienne remonte de 6 31/32 à 7 et la poubelle do 6 23/32 à 6 3/4, pendant que la part de fondateur gagne de son côté anne domi-livre à 50 1/2.
Tout le reste de la côte demeure soutenu.

On voit par ce bref exposé que la situation de notre corbeille des valeurs est exceptionnellement bonne pour la veille d'une liquidation. Celle-ci d'ailleurs d'annonce de jnar en jour comme plat facile; il n'y a plus guère de positions surchargées. Demain le marché reste fermé à l'occasion de la Toussaint. Il n'y a done plus que deux jours pour liquider on reporter.

Un million de Livres sterling. sont arrivées avant-hier à Alexandrie par le Cleopatra,” da Lloyd autrichien. Le Crédit Lyonnais a reçu 400,000 Livre', l'Anglo Egyptian Bank 250,000 Livres, la Banque Impériale.Ottomane 200,000 Livres, la Deutsche Orient Back 60,000, le Comptoir Financier et Commercial 80,000 Liv. res et le reste pour d'autres établissements financiers d'Egypte. .

Le Caire, Octobre 80. Le taux de l'escompte libre à Londres rasta à 5 7/8 pour rent. Au Stock Exchange, bier, le Consolide anglais a clôturé avarié à 86 118, de même gre l'Unifiée à 104. La National Bank est également demeurée ipohangée & 27 1/2, l'Agricole à 9.7/8 et la Daïra & 17. Senle la Delta Light a gagné 1/8 à 12 1/8.
A Paris, l'action Crédit Foncier Égyptien a olótaré en reprise de 3 francs à 783 et la Ban. que d'Athènes de 1 franc à 146.

Ici, nous avons eu, ce matin, une séance relativement calme, voire quelque peu lourde, ce qui est an offset naturel de la liquidation de fin de moie. Lo tassement a été, il est vrai, pea important, mais il n'est pas impossible qu'il persiste et s'accentue même demain. C mouvement de réaction n'est nullement inquiétant ; tout au contraire, il est plutôt rassurant, et il faut le surveiller attentivement en ce Sens qu'il pourrait bien être le prélude done proche poussée à la reprise. Celle-ci doit, en effet, forcément se produire dans les premiers jours du mois prochain, aussitôt qae. l'argent commencera à être plus abondant. Il y a done lieu de tirer parti des bas coors qui pourraient être pratiqués pour profiter largement de la baisse.

Dans le compartiment des Banques, la National a faibli & 27 1/4-5/16 et l'Agricole à 9 3/4 18/16. La Cassa di sconto s'est alourdie $ 210 l'action ancienne et 235 la nouvelle. La Comptoir Financier gat revena à 6 15/16-7 l'action angine et 6 11/16 la nouvelle.

Le Crédit Foncier a été mieux tena à 7611 782. La Daïra s'est tassée à 16 7/8-15/16. La Bébéar a débuté à 46 pour atteindre 47 et actionner à 44 1/2. L'Union Foncière s'est maintep ae 6 1/2-9/16. : La Nile Land s'est inscrite à 16 11916-3/4. L'Immobilière a décliné à 380 381 ; la part de fondateur est restée à 725-730. La part de fondateur Agricole du Nil a avancé à 9 5/8-11/16. L'Enterprise and Development a progressé à 18 7/8-15/16 ; la part de fondateur a été traitée $ 22. Les Improvements ont perdu 1/8 8 6 3/16 1/4 et les Allotments 1/16 à 3 7/8-15/16 ; lear part de fondateur & Ale hi à 163. Les parts de fondateur Gbarbieb Land, dont le prix de c! tore d'hier était . passablement nominal, ont fiait aux abords de 2 1/2.
L'action Bat Reprises Immobilières et Travaux a été bien tepu? à 4 1/2-9/16; la part de fondateur a oltaré & 97.
